comments.body:
for the curious, this is because the JWKS URL published in the OIDC discovery doc defaults to using the `--external-hostname`, expecting that to be generally resolveable.

local-up-cluster sets `--external-hostname=localhost` which is... not generally resolveable.

`--service-account-jwks-uri` gives the cluster deployer complete control over the JWKS hostname and can be used to alter the address used.
neat

      --service-account-signing-key-file="${SERVICE_ACCOUNT_KEY}" \
      --enable-admission-plugins="${ENABLE_ADMISSION_PLUGINS}" \

comments.body: is this a single flag when set?
yes it is https://cs.k8s.io/?q=priv_arg&i=nope&files=&repos=kubernetes/kubernetes
`${priv_arg:+"$priv_arg"}` will avoid splitting issues and _also_ not become an empty string
@caesarxuchao let's do `${priv_arg:+"$priv_arg"}`, this will expand to a single flag (shell word / array entry) if set to a non-empty string and otherwise not expand to anything.

Confirming my understanding is correct - the `()` is added because we want to quote `--cluster-dns...` and `--cluster-domain=...` separately?

Does shellcheck complain if we quote them together?

This is a change to split into each option.
dns_args have to be quoted for fixing the following shellcheck message.

In ./hack/local-up-cluster.sh line 774:
      ${dns_args}
      ^---------^ SC2206: Quote to prevent word splitting, or split robustly with mapfile or read -a.

If dns_args not defined as an array, it was executed as one option.

e.g.
hyperkube kubelet --allow-privileged=true ... '--cluster-dns=10.0.0.10 --cluster-domain=cluster.local' port=10250

comments.body:
I made a mistake and might have deleted your comment.

> Can you share more about the use of mapfile here?
> It looks like the shellcheck message related more to the double quote issues?


APISERVER_PIDS is the command line option and must be split on newlines.
It does not work by just double quoting and should be defined as an array.
And shellcheck displayed SC2206 when I used () to define APISERVER_PIDS as an array.
So I used mapfile.

https://github.com/koalaman/shellcheck/wiki/SC2206

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +349,353 @@  # Check if the API server is still running
  [[ -n "${APISERVER_PID-}" ]] && mapfile -t APISERVER_PIDS < <(pgrep -P "${APISERVER_PID}" ; ps -o pid= -p "${APISERVER_PID}")
  [[ -n "${APISERVER_PIDS-}" ]] && sudo kill "${APISERVER_PIDS[@]}" 2>/dev/null

  # Check if the controller-manager is still running

comments.body: this change isn't described in the commit or PR description, what's going on here?

Yes, I will update the PR with this change. but basically if we don't run the kobeproxy with don't need to generate it certificates. It similar change that I did in this commit  https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/74269/commits/33a81a7882d71e5d8f4a3850947c1d87677bf783 for kubelet. In general I think it will be better if we move the generate certificates to each method that start the service 
so that apiserver, scheduler kubeproxy kubelet will generate certificates as well.

the CI system is basically running kubetest with the "local" deployment option (https://github.com/kubernetes/test-infra/blob/master/kubetest/local.go) and it needs the `make cross` for the end-to-end conformance test to work properly.

wouldn't it be better to just include this in the creation of the file above?

```
mode:"${KUBEPROXY_MODE}
```

Right now the default of this var will be â€œâ€. Would kubeproxy accept `mode: ` if this was unspecified?

Yes. Kube-proxy treats the empty mode as default mode - the iptables mode.
I sent a PR to clean up this, ref: https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/54738

comments.body: is this the discovery server accepting requestheader auth, or knowing what headers to use to send it along to the underlying servers? I expected the apiserver to add these in order to trust the proxied requests from the discovery server

> is this the discovery server accepting requestheader auth, or knowing what headers to use to send it along to the underlying servers? I expected the apiserver to add these in order to trust the proxied requests from the discovery server

This flag is used to check tokenreviews.  The request header flags are used to accept an auth-proxy.  The process will *also* attach proxy headers on proxied requests, but that isn't wired up yet.

The core API server already has the request-header flags in local-up-cluster.sh
ok. unrelatedly, we may want to remove the "X-" from the auth proxy headers some time soon, sounds like X prefixes aren't recommended any more

comments.body:
Why?
(Just curious)
@deads2k ^^

> Why?
> (Just curious)

Controllers should start running with their own identity.  Part of that will involved a bootstrapping identity with sufficient power to create services accounts and run the SA token secret generator, but it should not require full access.

RBAC will authorize based on specific permissions and non-RBAC authorizers will be able to authorize based on username, but neither need to grant full powers.

comments.body: No value necessary when the option is a bool?

Treating the flag as "present" to enable.  Might be overkill or too clever, but means we don't have to define true/1/yes semantics for a label.  We could treat this as a label set and use label semantics, but I imagine we'll want values broader than the label subset.

```
versionHandler := apiserver.APIVersionHandler("v1beta1", "v1beta2", "v1beta3")
```

I'm fine with present implies enable.
Fixed versionHandler in the commit - may want to wait for the rest to filter out
